text:
Hey Shaliendra, 
I appreciate you are very busy, hope to hear from you soon and that all is well!

Hey Pheya! 
apologies for not getting back sooner.

Lets get straight to your response.

- This is a great way to learn.
Some of my colleagues who are producers happen to be artists in their earlier roles compositors, 3D artists etc. One of our line producers recently hosted an exhibition in an art gallery. 

The point is having a background and understanding of what the work entails or even an appreciation of other art forms allows someone to collaborate in large team environments and succeed

- shotgun is great and thats what we use too. However you might find other similar tools at other places

-Interesting
Visual art is often used to showcase fashion.
Look forward to seeing what you come up with

-Tips for production role
Iâ€™d say reach out proactively to recruiters. meet in person when possible and show your interest in what you do while you are still at university. see if you can organize a class visit to some of the places you wish to work at(many of them will do it when they are not super busy)

in an interview talk about all the projects you have worked at, challenges, what did you learn especially the ones in a team.

if you have done something cool, talk about your role confidently(folks in the industry can see it without hard evidence, they are judging from experience and can see potential)

to add to this one of my co-ordinators graduated with a nice compositing reel and transitioned to a production role based on her interest. she is really good and gets us what artists need well before we even ask for it because of her background.

the artwork is really cool!
nice color palette

would be interesting to see what you guys do with your fashion project.

something out of the box, creative that gets noticed  will always help with getting that first role in a large company.

Let me know if you have more questions.
goodluck!
